articles.headline: A Promising Drug With a Flaw
articles.snippet: The anticlotting drug Pradaxa, on the market only two years, is growing in popularity for its ease of use, but it has been associated with hemorrhaging, and it has no antidote to reverse its blood-thinning effects.
articles.abstract: The anticlotting drug Pradaxa, on the market only two years, is growing in popularity for its ease of use, but it has been associated with hemorrhaging, and it has no antidote to reverse its blood-thinning effects.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dr. Bryan A. Cotton, a trauma surgeon in Houston, had not heard much about the new anticlotting drug Pradaxa other than the commercials he had seen during Sunday football games.

articles.headline: Being Elected Is No Shield Against Money Woes
articles.snippet: Ordinary voters aren’t the only ones to confront foreclosures, tax woes and child-support payment problems. Consider the situation of Representative Joe Walsh, Republican of Illinois.
articles.abstract: Ordinary voters aren’t the only ones to confront foreclosures, tax woes and child-support payment problems. Consider the situation of Representative Joe Walsh, Republican of Illinois.
articles.lead_paragraph: Right or wrong, many voters think their elected representatives are above it all financially.

articles.headline:
Petraeus’s Quieter
Style at C.I.A. Leaves
Void on Libya Furor
articles.snippet: The Benghazi crisis has been the biggest challenge in the first civilian job held by David H. Petraeus, who has gotten high marks in a markedly different culture from that of the military.
articles.abstract: The Benghazi crisis has been the biggest challenge in the first civilian job held by David H. Petraeus, who has gotten high marks in a markedly different culture from that of the military.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 14 months as C.I.A. director, David H. Petraeus has shunned the spotlight he once courted as America’s most famous general. His low-profile style has won the loyalty of the White House, easing old tensions with President Obama, and he has overcome some of the skepticism he faced from the agency’s work force, which is always wary of the military brass.

articles.headline: Military to Deliver Fuel to Storm-Ravaged Region
articles.snippet: With lines at Northeast gas stations persisting, the government turned to the Pentagon for help and eased limits on foreign tankers.
articles.abstract: With lines at Northeast gas stations persisting, the government turned to the Pentagon for help and eased limits on foreign tankers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As long lines persisted at gas stations in the New York metropolitan area, federal authorities moved on Friday to restore supplies, instructing the Defense Department to send 24 million gallons of fuel to the region and lifting restrictions on deliveries by foreign-flagged ships.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: For Some After the Storm, No Work Means No Pay
articles.snippet: Thousands of hourly workers took extreme measures to get to work following Hurricane Sandy with the fear that if they did not go to work , they probably would not be paid.
articles.abstract: Thousands of hourly workers took extreme measures to get to work following Hurricane Sandy with the fear that if they did not go to work , they probably would not be paid.
articles.lead_paragraph: Chantal Sainvilus, a home health aide in Brooklyn who makes $10 an hour, does not get paid if she does not show up. So it is no wonder that she joined the thousands of people taking extreme measures to get to work this week, even, in her case, hiking over the Williamsburg Bridge.
articles.byline: By Shaila Dewan and Andrew Martin

articles.headline: With Time as Tight as Race, Romney and Obama Zero In
articles.snippet: For President Obama and Mitt Romney, a stubborn landscape of competitive states is producing equal shares of hope and fear amid conflicting signals about the outcome.
articles.abstract: For President Obama and Mitt Romney, a stubborn landscape of competitive states is producing equal shares of hope and fear amid conflicting signals about the outcome.
articles.lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — President Obama and Mitt Romney entered their final weekend of campaigning on Saturday facing a stubborn landscape of competitive states that right to the end are producing equal shares of hope and fear amid conflicting signals about the outcome.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Party Planning, for Both Victory and Defeat
articles.snippet: As a feat of event planning, there is nothing quite like an election-night party, which could be an evening of triumph or fiasco, a celebration or a wake.
articles.abstract: As a feat of event planning, there is nothing quite like an election-night party, which could be an evening of triumph or fiasco, a celebration or a wake.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS

articles.headline: One Safety Net That Needs to Shrink
articles.snippet: Eight lucky financial institutions got the best of both worlds under Dodd-Frank: access to the Fed’s money and no penalty for failure.
articles.abstract: Eight lucky financial institutions got the best of both worlds under Dodd-Frank: access to the Fed’s money and no penalty for failure.
articles.lead_paragraph: ELECTION Day is upon us, and neither President Obama nor Mitt Romney has really addressed one of the nation’s most pressing economic issues: the risk that one day taxpayers might have to bail out swashbuckling financial institutions again.

articles.headline: Google Casts a Big Shadow on Smaller Web Sites
articles.snippet: For Web sites that depend on their ranking in search results, Google’s secret — and frequently fluctuating — search algorithm can evoke a complex blend of admiration and fear.
articles.abstract: For Web sites that depend on their ranking in search results, Google’s secret — and frequently fluctuating — search algorithm can evoke a complex blend of admiration and fear.
articles.lead_paragraph: STARTING in February, Jeffrey G. Katz grew increasingly anxious as he watched the steady decline of online traffic to his company’s comparison-shopping Web site, Nextag, from Google’s search engine.
articles.byline: By Steve Lohr and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: Getting Out the Ohio Vote, Campaigns Are a Study in Contrasts
articles.snippet: As a marathon campaign in Ohio nears a conclusion, the contest has become political trench warfare, President Obama’s intricate operation jousting with the raw drive of Mitt Romney’s field team.
articles.abstract: As a marathon campaign in Ohio nears a conclusion, the contest has become political trench warfare, President Obama’s intricate operation jousting with the raw drive of Mitt Romney’s field team.
articles.lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — Inside a peeling former nightclub here, Obama volunteers are perched on any seats they can find, trays of half-eaten sandwiches line an old mirrored bar and a hand-scrawled list of “office needs” includes toilet paper and Teddy Grahams.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Michael Wines

articles.headline: As Candidates Make Final Pleas, Legal Battles Begin
articles.snippet: President Obama and Mitt Romney hunted for support in battleground states even as their parties faced off in the first court skirmishes over presidential ballots and how they are counted.
articles.abstract: President Obama and Mitt Romney hunted for support in battleground states even as their parties faced off in the first court skirmishes over presidential ballots and how they are counted.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOLLYWOOD, Fla. — President Obama and Mitt Romney hunted for last-minute support on Sunday in a frenetic sprint across battleground states, even as their parties faced off in the first of what could be a growing number of legal disputes over presidential ballots and how they are counted.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: A Storm-Battered Supply Chain Threatens Holiday Shopping
articles.snippet: In addition to shutting down shipping terminals and submerging warehouses, the storm tangled up deliveries, just as retailers normally receive final shipments for the holiday shopping season.
articles.abstract: In addition to shutting down shipping terminals and submerging warehouses, the storm tangled up deliveries, just as retailers normally receive final shipments for the holiday shopping season.
articles.lead_paragraph: The economic effects of Hurricane Sandy are reverberating beyond areas hit by the storm as businesses warn customers of delays, try to get merchandise out of closed ports and face canceled orders.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: Fight Builds Over Online Royalties
articles.snippet: New legislation pressed by Pandora Media and other Internet radio services to reduce their royalty rates has touched a nerve in the music industry.
articles.abstract: New legislation pressed by Pandora Media and other Internet radio services to reduce their royalty rates has touched a nerve in the music industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: The debate playing out in Washington has echoes of a presidential race. One side says businesses will suffer unless the government steps in to lower costs. The other accuses jet-set industrialists of a ploy that will cheat the middle class.

articles.headline: Booksellers Resisting Amazon’s Disruption
articles.snippet: The mammoth retailer finds that its efforts to upend the traditional publishing model have unintended consequences.
articles.abstract: The mammoth retailer finds that its efforts to upend the traditional publishing model have unintended consequences.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Amazon prides itself on unraveling the established order. This fall, signs of Amazon-inspired disruption are everywhere.

articles.headline: Publishers Abroad Take On Google
articles.snippet: Publishers in Europe and South America have joined anew in the fight against Google, arguing that it is picking their pockets every time it links to articles.
articles.abstract: Publishers in Europe and South America have joined anew in the fight against Google, arguing that it is picking their pockets every time it links to articles.
articles.lead_paragraph: They say you should never take on people who spill ink by the barrel, but your odds are better when you traffic in terabytes of data. In the United States, Google and big media went at it for several years over Google News and Google won, taking its argument for a free and open Internet all the way to the bank.

articles.headline: Facing an Election Night Clamor
articles.snippet: After several missteps this year, news organizations have fine-tuned their safeguards and tried to prepare for a huge influx of social media reaction.
articles.abstract: After several missteps this year, news organizations have fine-tuned their safeguards and tried to prepare for a huge influx of social media reaction.
articles.lead_paragraph: This has been the year of the big media gaffe.

articles.headline: As Scandal Flared, BBC’s Leaders Missed Red Flags
articles.snippet: Interviews with former BBC officials suggest that Mark Thompson and his top executives repeatedly missed opportunities to pursue a fuller picture of the BBC’s investigation into Jimmy Savile.
articles.abstract: Interviews with former BBC officials suggest that Mark Thompson and his top executives repeatedly missed opportunities to pursue a fuller picture of the BBC’s investigation into Jimmy Savile.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Last March, Mark Thompson addressed the Royal Television Society and took proud stock of his time leading the BBC, Britain’s publicly financed media behemoth that is both treasure and target. He had successfully navigated eight years of political wrangling, the digital revolution, controversies over cost-cutting and his own pay, not to mention some cringe-making televised antics of BBC hosts.

articles.headline: Romney, a Challenger at the Crossroads
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney has arrived at a strange and unfamiliar moment. The political prize that eluded him four years ago, and his father, George, decades before that, is suddenly within agonizingly close reach.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney has arrived at a strange and unfamiliar moment. The political prize that eluded him four years ago, and his father, George, decades before that, is suddenly within agonizingly close reach.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER — As he ponders two futures, one in the White House, the other back home in Belmont, Mass., Mitt Romney is juggling two books: “Mornings on Horseback,” a biography of President Theodore Roosevelt, and “The Faithful Spy,” an escapist thriller about a daring C.I.A. agent.
articles.byline: By Ashley Parker and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: A President’s Last Race, Win or Lose
articles.snippet: President Obama’s checklist of “lasts” grew longer as he raced through a bone-weary last weekend before Tuesday’s election.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s checklist of “lasts” grew longer as he raced through a bone-weary last weekend before Tuesday’s election.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRISTOW, Va. — President Obama looked out at the sea of shivering supporters at a chilly late-night rally here and soaked in the wave of blue campaign placards and the flashing of a thousand smartphone cameras.

articles.headline: HSBC May Face Charges in a Laundering Inquiry
articles.snippet: The British bank HSBC has set aside an additional $800 million connected to a money laundering investigation in the United States and says it may face criminal charges in the United States.
articles.abstract: The British bank HSBC has set aside an additional $800 million connected to a money laundering investigation in the United States and says it may face criminal charges in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: 9:28 p.m. | Updated
articles.byline: By Mark Scott and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Toyota Raises Forecast Despite Lag in China
articles.snippet: The carmaker, which expects to make $9.7 billion for the full year through March, has been less exposed than its Japanese peers to the fallout over a territorial dispute with China.
articles.abstract: The carmaker, which expects to make $9.7 billion for the full year through March, has been less exposed than its Japanese peers to the fallout over a territorial dispute with China.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — In the biggest sign yet of a strong recovery for Toyota Motor, the automaker raised its full-year profit forecast on Monday, shrugging off a sales decline in China brought about by a territorial spat between the two countries.

articles.headline: Deal Maker for Morgan Stanley Is Eased Out
articles.snippet: Morgan Stanley said on Monday that Paul J. Taubman, one of the co-heads of its core securities arm and a top deal maker, would retire at the end of the year, in an unexpected shake-up of the firm’s senior management.
articles.abstract: Morgan Stanley said on Monday that Paul J. Taubman, one of the co-heads of its core securities arm and a top deal maker, would retire at the end of the year, in an unexpected shake-up of the firm’s senior management.
articles.lead_paragraph: 10:35 a.m. | Updated
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Susanne Craig
